text:
The Rustaceans are making all the cool command-line tools. Just now, someone released a multithreaded and SIMD-parallelized tool to uwu-fy source text. It's capable of making your source text kawaii at gigabytes per second:
<https://github.com/Daniel-Liu-c0deb0t/uwu>
It's just a matter of time before Daniel Lemire postd about it on his blog

elements.text: The Rustaceans are making all the cool command-line tools. Just now, someone released a multithreaded and SIMD-parallelized tool to uwu-fy source text. It's capable of making your source text kawaii at gigabytes per second:
It's just a matter of time before Daniel Lemire postd about it on his blog

text: I've been spending some time in the Rust community and its pretty great, like lots of "passion projects", maybe more goofing around then there ought to be, but yea Rust has really opened up a doorway for people to mess around with things they otherwise wouldn't. Systems programming as a hobby actually has a pretty large population now days haha

text: <@UPUBAM63X> I wonder if that is because the Julia community is more able to use Julia in their jobs, whereas Rust programmers need to reserve it for side projects, just due to the difference in audiences.

elements.text: I wonder if that is because the Julia community is more able to use Julia in their jobs, whereas Rust programmers need to reserve it for side projects, just due to the difference in audiences.

text: god I love this project so much. Multithreaded SIMD uwu-ification.

elements.text: god I love this project so much. Multithreaded SIMD uwu-ification.

text: > Our contributions in this paper are threefold: first, we present, to our knowledge, the first rigorous definition of uwu'd text. Second, we show our novel algorithms for uwu-ing text, exploiting vectorization and multithreading features that are available on modern CPUs.

elements.text: Our contributions in this paper are threefold: first, we present, to our knowledge, the first rigorous definition of uwu'd text. Second, we show our novel algorithms for uwu-ing text, exploiting vectorization and multithreading features that are available on modern CPUs.

text:
The source code, though:
```    // only the highest quality seed will do
    let mut rng = XorShift32::new(b"uwu!");```
And of course, you can't let those pesky branch midpredictions slow cute stuttering down the slightest bit:
```            // decide whether to stutter in a branchless way
            // a branch would mispredict often since this is random
            let increment = if rng.gen_bool() { 2 } else { 0 };
            _mm_storeu_si128(out_ptr.add(stutter_idx + increment) as *mut __m128i, res);```
And of course
> _// TODO: write paper_
> _// TODO: write more about machine learning so i get funding_
